title: Quiz 6: Life Cycle & Genetics
description: Assessment covering Introduction to Genetics (Ch 17) and The Reproductive Systems (Ch 18). Focuses on inheritance, DNA structure, male and female reproductive anatomy, the menstrual cycle, and fertilization.

questions.question: In the structure of DNA, which nitrogenous base always pairs with Cytosine (C)?
questions.explanation: DNA base pairing is specific: Adenine pairs with Thymine (A-T), and Cytosine pairs with Guanine (C-G). Uracil replaces Thymine in RNA.
questions.hint: C-G (Curved letters go together), A-T (Angular letters go together).

questions.question: Trace the path of a sperm cell from production to ejaculation.
questions.explanation: Sperm are made in the testes, mature in the epididymis, travel up the vas deferens, join seminal fluids in the ejaculatory duct, and exit via the urethra.
questions.hint: Production -> Storage -> Transport tube -> Mixing -> Exit.

questions.question: Match the layer of the uterine wall with its description:

pairs.right: Thick middle layer of smooth muscle
Inner mucous lining functioning in menstruation

questions.explanation: Peri=Around/Outer. Myo=Muscle. Endo=Inside.
questions.hint: Which layer causes contractions during labor?

questions.question: Which hormone spike is primarily responsible for triggering ovulation around day 14 of the menstrual cycle?
questions.explanation: A sudden surge in LH from the anterior pituitary triggers the rupture of the mature follicle (ovulation).

questions.question: A normal human body cell (somatic cell) contains ___BLANK___ pairs of chromosomes, for a total of 46.
questions.explanation: Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes (diploid number). Gametes have 23 single chromosomes (haploid number).

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the prostate gland are correct? (Select all that apply)

options.text: It surrounds the urethra just below the bladder
It secretes a thin, milky, alkaline fluid
It is the site of spermatogenesis

questions.explanation: The prostate surrounds the urethra and adds alkaline fluid to semen. Testosterone is from the testes; sperm is from the testes.
questions.hint: Think about why older men often have trouble urinating.

questions.question: What is the term for the specific site in the female reproductive tract where fertilisation usually occurs?
questions.explanation: Fertilisation usually occurs in the uterine tubes (Fallopian tubes), specifically in the ampulla.
questions.hint: The tube connecting the ovary to the uterus.

questions.question: Match the genetic term with its definition:

pairs.right: The genetic makeup of an individual
Having two identical alleles for a trait
Having two different alleles for a trait

questions.explanation: Genotype = Genes. Phenotype = Physical appearance. Homo = Same. Hetero = Different.
questions.hint: Phenotype starts with P for Physical.

questions.question: What is the primary function of the corpus luteum following ovulation?

options.text: To produce FSH to stimulate new follicles
To secrete Progesterone (and some oestrogen) to maintain the endometrium

questions.explanation: The corpus luteum secretes progesterone to maintain the thickened endometrium for potential implantation. If pregnancy doesn't occur, it degenerates.
questions.hint: It maintains the 'bed' for the embryo.

questions.question: Meiosis results in two daughter cells that are genetically identical to the parent cell.
questions.explanation: FALSE. MITOSIS creates identical cells. MEIOSIS produces four genetically unique haploid gametes (sperm/ova).
questions.hint: Meiosis makes 'Me' (a unique individual via sex cells).

questions.question: If a father is heterozygous for a dominant trait (Tt) and the mother is homozygous recessive (tt), what is the probability of their child displaying the dominant trait?

richContent.content:
Punnett Square Hint:

Father: T, t

Mother: t, t

questions.explanation: The possible combinations are Tt, Tt, tt, tt. Two out of four (50%) have the dominant 'T' allele.
questions.hint: Draw the square: Tt x tt.

questions.question: Which of the following are functions of Testosterone? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Development of male secondary sexual characteristics

questions.explanation: Testosterone drives male characteristics, sperm production, and anabolic growth (muscle/bone). Prolactin stimulates milk.

questions.question: Arrange the phases of the female reproductive cycle (28-day cycle) in order.
questions.explanation: Bleeding (Menstrual) -> Rebuilding (Proliferative) -> Release (Ovulation) -> Preparation for pregnancy (Secretory).

questions.question: The fertilized ovum is called a ___BLANK___. It contains 46 chromosomes.
questions.explanation: Fusion of sperm (23) and ovum (23) creates a diploid zygote (46).

questions.question: Why are the testes located in the scrotum outside the abdominal cavity?

options.text: To protect them from abdominal pressure
To maintain a temperature lower than body temperature for sperm production
To facilitate easier transport of sperm

questions.explanation: Spermatogenesis requires a temperature about 3Â°C lower than core body temperature.

questions.question: Match the reproductive hormone with its primary effect:

pairs.right: Stimulates uterine contractions and milk ejection

questions.explanation: FSH=Follicle/Gamete start. LH=Hormone release/Ovulation. Prolactin=Production of milk. Oxytocin=Output (Ejection/Labor).

questions.question: Red-green colour blindness is an example of a sex-linked (X-linked) inheritance.
questions.explanation: True. The gene is on the X chromosome. Males (XY) only need one faulty gene to be color blind; females (XX) need two.
questions.hint: Why does it affect men more than women?

questions.question: What is the term for the cessation of the reproductive cycles in females, usually occurring between 45 and 55 years of age?
questions.explanation: Menopause is the end of menstruation and fertility due to ovarian follicle exhaustion.

questions.question: Which structure carries the genetic instructions for a single protein?
questions.explanation: A gene is a specific sequence of DNA that codes for a protein. A chromosome contains many genes. The genome is the total genetic material.

questions.question: Which of the following are components of the external female genitalia (vulva)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The vulva includes the labia, clitoris, and vestibule. The cervix (neck of uterus) and ovaries are internal.

questions.question: A cell with a full set of 46 chromosomes is described as ___BLANK___, while a gamete with 23 chromosomes is ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Diploid (2n) = 46. Haploid (n) = 23 (Half).
questions.hint: Di- means two (sets); Hap- sounds like Half.

questions.question: What is the name of the cell division process that produces gametes (sperm and ova)?
questions.explanation: Meiosis reduces the chromosome number by half to produce gametes. Mitosis replicates somatic cells.

questions.question: Which accessory gland contributes the majority (60%) of the fluid volume to semen, including fructose for energy?
questions.explanation: Seminal vesicles secrete a viscous, alkaline fluid with fructose. Prostate contributes about 30%.

questions.question: Mitochondrial DNA is inherited exclusively from the father.
questions.explanation: FALSE. Mitochondrial DNA is inherited exclusively from the MOTHER via the ovum.

questions.question: What is the result of a mutation?

options.text: A change in the genetic material (DNA) of a cell
A change in the cell membrane structure

questions.explanation: A mutation is a change in DNA. It can be beneficial, harmful (lethal or disease-causing), or neutral.
